Silent forms of protest is a protected expression that you shouldn't be punished for.
  

Learn your rights!

Silent forms of protest, such as sitting down during the pledge or taking a knee while the anthem, is a protected expression.

Dear ##first_name[Supporter]##,

In October, we sent a letter to the Lowndes County School District (LCSD) in support of public school students' right to protest. The school district's attorney, who also serves as a state representative, has proposed a policy that would not only require students to stand for the national anthem, but would require everyone attending sporting events to do the same. That's right – the LCSD attorney wants to make fans stand for the anthem whether they like it or not. He even stated in a news article that the Mississippi High School Activities Association is considering his policy.

Read our letters to the Lowndes Country School District.

Let's be clear – silent forms of protest, such as sitting down while the pledge is being delivered or taking a knee while the anthem is being sung at sporting events, is protected expression and no school official may punish you for doing so. It doesn't matter if your protest takes place during a mandatory school activity or during a voluntary activity, like at an extracurricular sporting event. As long as you're not being disruptive, you cannot be punished or forced to participate. In addition, it is unconstitutional for any governmental entity to implement policies that would violate that First Amendment right.

Students have rights, too. Download our Students Rights Manual and know your rights!

In solidarity,

Jennifer Riley-Collins
Executive Director
ACLU of Mississippi
